bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, March 23, 1900

div1.p: Lazear writes that he will assist Reed in an investigation of a disinfectant. He offers his opinion on the political situation in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, March 23, 1900
div1.opener:
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
Columbia Barracks
Havana Cuba
March 23, 1900
Baltimore.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P.M.
My dear Mother
div1.p:
I am afraid I am a day or two
late with my letter. I have been very busy
lately. Major Reed has been in Havana on a
special mission to investigate a disinfectant
and I have been detailed to assist him.
It has taken up a great deal of my
time.

I am sorry you were worried about my not
mentioning the box. It was Mabel who
wrote to you about the things and as I
did not have need of anything I left the
whole matter to her. I did not show her
Your letters so she did not know you
were waiting. She leaves here on the
Transport “Sedgwick” which will sail on
or about Apr. 15 for New York.

Mrs. Shuter came out here the day she
arrived. She did not seen pleased with
her quarters in town. Havana is a strange
sort of place and bewilders one unless
one is an old traveller.

Houston gets along very well. He is very
active and good natured all day but he
has tantrums at night.

I have written to the Brandts about
having the placards in the windows.

I wish however you would see them
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
BALTIMORE.
sometimes and speak to them about trying
to rent the house. Did you make
out the inventory of the furniture?
The Halls go out on April you know and
I would be much obliged if you would
call there after they have gone and see
if everything is all right. I told Mr Brandt
to try to rent unfurnished and if he
succeeded to let you know so you could
superintend U moving the thing to the warehouse.
I told him also that if he could not rent
if unfurnished but found a good tenant who
wanted it furnished to let it go to him.
In spite of the published interview with Sec. Root.
I do not think there is any intention
of giving up Cuba. Expensive improvements
are still being made here. Nearly
all the substantial business be men wish
us to stay. The impatient ones are
chiefly those who wish to get there hands
into the treasury.

I received Alex's inclosure. It required
no answer.
